image.altText: A red stage with Qantas logo on projector

items.synopsis: Qantas is holding its AGM, just a few days after the airline defended itself against so-called "ghost flight" allegations. Follow proceedings as they happen with our live blog.

title.children: Qantas board on notice after 83pc protest vote by shareholders over executive pay

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Coles is also hosting its annual general meeting in Melbourne today, and it's seen more than 50 Coles workers, unionists and activists stage a protest outside, calling for higher wages, more security in stores and an end to what they describe as price gouging. About 200 members of the Retail and Fast Food Workers Union in Victoria went on strike on Friday while an extra 400 in other states held shorter stoppages, according to the union. "Workers are paid poverty wages in unsafe workplaces, they've got insecure jobs and we need that to change," union secretary Josh Cullinan said. "Our members can't afford the groceries that they sell." Mr Cullinan said the strike was purposefully staged on the day of the annual meeting and was critical of the gathering being held in a complex protected by police and security guards when ordinary workers didn't have that level of safety. Coles worker and union delegate Nelio Da Silva said a lot of staff at his store were struggling and abuse against workers was on the rise. "The $1.1 billion in profit Coles has made, that needs to be shared around amongst workers, the community, everyone," Mr Da Silva said. Inside, Coles chair James Graham told the meeting the supermarket giant had 120,000 team members and that the Retail and Fast Food Workers Union represented around 500 of them. Coles was negotiating with the union in good faith, as it would with any representative for its workers, he said. "Because we need to have a positive and supportive relationships with our team members, in order that we can conduct our business in a way which we're proud of, and our customers enjoy and feel comfortable with," Mr Graham said. Twice-yearly surveys that Coles conducts of its team members found that most are positive, confident and proud to recommend Coles, he said. "But there will be inevitably be issues … and we'll work those issues through." — AAP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Coles workers protest outside supermarket giant's AGM in Melbourne

children.content: Coles

is also hosting its annual general meeting in Melbourne today, and it's seen more than 50 Coles workers, unionists and activists stage a protest outside, calling for higher wages, more security in stores and an end to what they describe as price gouging.
About 200 members of the Retail and Fast Food Workers Union in Victoria went on strike on Friday while an extra 400 in other states held shorter stoppages, according to the union.
"Workers are paid poverty wages in unsafe workplaces, they've got insecure jobs and we need that to change," union secretary Josh Cullinan said.
"Our members can't afford the groceries that they sell."

Mr Cullinan said the strike was purposefully staged on the day of the annual meeting and was critical of the gathering being held in a complex protected by police and security guards when ordinary workers didn't have that level of safety.
Coles worker and union delegate Nelio Da Silva said a lot of staff at his store were struggling and abuse against workers was on the rise.
"The $1.1 billion in profit Coles has made, that needs to be shared around amongst workers, the community, everyone," Mr Da Silva said.
Inside, Coles chair James Graham told the meeting the supermarket giant had 120,000 team members and that the Retail and Fast Food Workers Union represented around 500 of them.
Coles was negotiating with the union in good faith, as it would with any representative for its workers, he said.

"Because we need to have a positive and supportive relationships with our team members, in order that we can conduct our business in a way which we're proud of, and our customers enjoy and feel comfortable with," Mr Graham said.
Twice-yearly surveys that Coles conducts of its team members found that most are positive, confident and proud to recommend Coles, he said.
"But there will be inevitably be issues … and we'll work those issues through."
— AAP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Labor Senator Tony Sheldon has issued a statement a short time ago about the Qantas AGM, and it echoes that shared by the TWU earlier — that chair Richard Goyder needs to leave the airline now. Senator Sheldon, who was previously the national secretary of the TWU, said the airline's AGM capped off "another week of horror at the airline, with arrogance and platitudes in abundance". "Qantas Chair Richard Goyder continued to defend the illegal sacking of 1,700 people, insisting that the company needed to carry out the sacking despite receiving a $2.7 billion bailout from the Morrison government," he said. "They apologised for getting caught sacking 1,700 workers illegally. They apologised for getting caught ripping off travel credits. They 'apologise' for poor management but still pay themselves massive bonuses and say its all for 'sound commercial reasons'. "Goyder's persistent refusal to sincerely apologise and admit fault over the largest illegal sacking in Australian history makes him unfit to serve as Qantas Chair for another day, let alone for the duration of his extended farewell tour. "The overwhelming 83% strike against Qantas' remuneration report sums up the near-unanimous disdain that the Australian public and workforce has for the Qantas Board and its executive. "Qantas shareholders displayed far greater mercy to Todd Sampson today than he and his board colleagues ever did to the 1,700 working families whose lives they illegally destroyed." Mr Goyder has previously announced he would leave the airline by the end of next year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Protest vote shows the 'near-unanimous disdain' the public has for Qantas, Senator says

children.content: Labor Senator Tony Sheldon has issued a statement a short time ago about the Qantas AGM, and it echoes that shared by the TWU earlier — that chair Richard Goyder needs to leave the airline now.
Senator Sheldon, who was previously the national secretary of the TWU, said the airline's AGM capped off "another week of horror at the airline, with arrogance and platitudes in abundance".

"Qantas Chair Richard Goyder continued to defend the illegal sacking of 1,700 people, insisting that the company needed to carry out the sacking despite receiving a $2.7 billion bailout from the Morrison government," he said.

"They apologised for getting caught sacking 1,700 workers illegally. They apologised for getting caught ripping off travel credits. They 'apologise' for poor management but still pay themselves massive bonuses and say its all for 'sound commercial reasons'.

"Goyder's persistent refusal to sincerely apologise and admit fault over the largest illegal sacking in Australian history makes him unfit to serve as Qantas Chair for another day, let alone for the duration of his extended farewell tour.
"The overwhelming 83% strike against Qantas' remuneration report sums up the near-unanimous disdain that the Australian public and workforce has for the Qantas Board and its executive.
"Qantas shareholders displayed far greater mercy to Todd Sampson today than he and his board colleagues ever did to the 1,700 working families whose lives they illegally destroyed."
Mr Goyder has previously announced he would leave the airline by the end of next year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We sure have — but not only is Qantas' 83% protest vote the first remuneration strike for the airline, it's also one of the biggest in Australian corporate history. The record for the highest-ever protest vote at an AGM is widely thought to be held by NAB, which copped a staggering 88% protest vote in 2018 in the wake of the banking royal commission. NAB's protest vote currently holds the record for the largest since the voting scheme was introduced back in 2005. Westpac was also hit with a 64% protest vote in 2018, and received a 30% protest vote again in 2021.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Have we seen substantial protest votes against companies before?

children.content: We sure have — but not only is Qantas' 83% protest vote the first remuneration strike for the airline, it's also one of the biggest in Australian corporate history.
The record for the highest-ever protest vote at an AGM is widely thought to be held by NAB, which copped a staggering 88% protest vote in 2018 in the wake of the banking royal commission.
NAB's protest vote currently holds the record for the largest since the voting scheme was introduced back in 2005.
Westpac was also hit with a 64% protest vote in 2018, and received a 30% protest vote again in 2021.

image.altText: a woman standing in a pew in a packed church

items.synopsis: The life and legacy of Labor giant Bill Hayden is being honoured at a state funeral service in his hometown south-west of Brisbane today. Watch live.

title.children: Political heavyweights, friends and family come together for Bill Hayden's state funeral

image.altText: A court sketch of Erin Patterson.

items.synopsis: Prosecutors say it will take months to analyse computer equipment seized from the home of a woman charged with murder over a mushroom meal linked to three deaths in Victoria's east.

title.children: Erin Patterson faces court after police lay murder charges over mushroom meal

image.altText: Former Israeli PM defends civilian casualities in Gaza

items.synopsis: Seven United Nations special rapporteurs issue a warning about the risk of genocide, but Israel says it is aiming its attacks at Hamas not civilians. Follow live.

title.children: Israeli opposition leader blames Hamas as UN raises risk of Palestinian genocide

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel will return Gazans working inside the country to the besieged Palestinian territory, the government says. "Israel is severing all contact with Gaza. There will be no more Palestinian workers from Gaza," the Israeli security cabinet announced in a statement late Thursday. "Those workers from Gaza who were in Israel on the day of the outbreak of the war will be returned to Gaza," it added, without specifying how many people would be sent back. Before the start of the war, Israel had issued work permits to some 18,500 Gazans, according to COGAT, the Israeli defence body responsible for Palestinian civilian affairs. COGAT did not immediately return a request for information on the number of Gazans working inside Israel at the time of the attack on October 7. Reporting with AFP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel says it will return Gazan labourers to the enclave and sever 'all contact'

children.content: Israel
will return
Gazans working inside the country
to the besieged Palestinian territory, the government says.
"Israel is severing all contact with Gaza. There will be no more Palestinian workers from Gaza," the Israeli security cabinet announced in a statement late Thursday.
"Those workers from Gaza who were in Israel on the day of the outbreak of the war will be returned to Gaza," it added, without specifying how many people would be sent back.
Before the start of the war, Israel had issued work permits to some
18,500 Gazans,
according to COGAT, the Israeli defence body responsible for Palestinian civilian affairs.
COGAT did not immediately return a request for information on the number of Gazans working inside Israel
at the time of the attack on October 7
Reporting with AFP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Two more Australians trapped in Gaza have been able to flee the enclave during the latest opening of the border crossing into Egypt, AAP reports citing a Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade spokesperson. One citizen and one permanent resident were able to exit through the Rafah crossing out of Gaza during the second window for foreign nationals to evacuate on Thursday. The Australians, who were on a list to get out of Gaza in the first opportunity on Wednesday, made the crossing into Egypt with the help of consular officials from the UK. They will join the rest of the other 23 Australians who got out of Gaza safely on Wednesday for onward travel to Cairo. "We continue to engage closely with partners in the region and do all we can to enable the remaining Australians in Gaza, who wish to leave, to do so as soon as possible," a foreign affairs department spokesman said. "The timing of those departures depends on a range of factors. "The situation in Gaza continues to be highly challenging and can change rapidly." More than 800 people have been able to leave Gaza via the Rafah crossing under a deal brokered between the US, Egypt, Israel and Qatar. A third crossing opportunity is expected to take place on Friday. Reporting with AAP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Two more Australians leave Gaza

out of Gaza during the second window for foreign nationals to evacuate on Thursday.
The Australians, who were on a list to get out of Gaza in the first opportunity on Wednesday, made the crossing into Egypt with the help of consular officials from the UK.
They will join the rest of the other 23 Australians who got out of Gaza safely on Wednesday for onward travel to
Cairo

"We continue to engage closely with partners in the region and do all we can to enable the remaining Australians in Gaza, who wish to leave, to do so as soon as possible," a foreign affairs department spokesman said.
"The timing of those departures depends on a range of factors.
"The situation in Gaza continues to be highly challenging and can change rapidly."
More than 800 people have been able to leave Gaza via the Rafah crossing under a deal brokered between the US, Egypt, Israel and Qatar.
A third crossing opportunity is expected to take place on Friday.
Reporting with AAP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The United States has been flying surveillance drones over Gaza in search of hostages taken by Hamas, two US officials said. The officials spoke with Reuters on condition of anonymity. One said they had been carrying out the drone flights for over a week. US officials have said 10 Americans who remain unaccounted for may be among the more than 200 people taken as hostages into Gaza, where they are believed to be held in Hamas's extensive tunnel network .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US flying drones over Gaza to help find hostages

children.content: The United States has been flying surveillance drones over Gaza in search of hostages taken by Hamas, two US officials said.
The officials spoke with Reuters on condition of anonymity.
One said they had been carrying out the drone flights for over a week.
US officials have said 10 Americans who remain unaccounted for may be among the more than 200 people taken as hostages into Gaza, where they are believed to be held in
Hamas's extensive tunnel network
